Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Enhanced Anaerobic Digestion of Wastewater Using Bioelectrodes
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project will develop an anaerobic digestion system which utilizes bio-electrodes to more efficiently convert wastewater into biogas and ultimately energy. Bio-electrochemical systems have received significant attention in recent years with the discovery of electricigen microbes capable of transferring electrons to and from electrodes at high rates. To date, most research has focused on using these processes in fuel-cell-like devices to produce electricity or hydrogen. In this project, IntAct will build and demonstrate a simplified process for enhanced anaerobic digestion based on adding electrodes and applying voltage directly into an AD chamber. The resulting proprietary system makes use of an applied voltage to modulate the growth of electricigen microbes on electrodes thus overcoming thermodynamic limitations to methane production and enabling pH control.

The broader/commercial impact of the proposed project will be the ability to recover increased amounts of energy from the wastewater treatment process.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This SBIR Phase I successfully demonstrated the suitability of Cambrian Innovation’s patent-pending Exogen™ bio-electrochemical Enhanced Anaerobic Digestion (EAD) technology for the energy positive treatment of industrial wastewater streams. Exogen™ uses anode / cathode pairs with applied voltages to facilitate the growth of exo-electrogenic biofilms. These exoelectrogenic microbial populations were identified to be present in wide ranging waste water sources. Anode biofilms remove chemical oxygen demand (COD) and cathode biofilms are capable of reducing CO2 to CH4, thereby increasing treatment rates and gas quality when compared to traditional anaerobic digestion processes. The technology was successfully utilized for the treatment of various industrial waste water streams, indicating a potential for wide-scale application.

System performance was optimized for a large range of COD concentrations, allowing for application of the technology as a late-stage anaerobic digester or a polishing step. The goal of this technology is to reduce or replace COD surcharges and aerobic polishing steps. The primary benefits of this application are (i) increased volumetric COD removal rate (kg COD/m3/day), (ii) increased total gas production, and (iii) improved methane fraction in the output biogas due to cathodic CO2 reduction to CH4. This makes the system ideal as an AD polishing step to AD processes. A systems analysis incorporating CapEx and OpEx demonstrates a payback period of 2 - 4 years.

Modified by: Matthew R Silver
